texts.shortText: Body firm and tough, quadrangular in cross-section with bottom surface somewhat flattened. Colour fairly uniform grey. Tube feet arranged in five fairly-indistinct bands, with 2-3 rows in each dorsal band and 2-4 rows in each ventral band. Tentacles 10, pale and transparent, each of same length and with fairly-short tree-like (dentritic) branching, the terminal branches ending in small swellings.
Body length typically about 80 mm, excluding tentacles (some sources say max 50 mm).

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambertâ€˜s Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.

A common species, but often found mixed with the Cask sea cucumber Pentacta doliolum, with which it is often confused. Typically found buried in course sediments composed of pebbles, broken shells etc. with the tentacles extended up into the water column, or among other sedentary invertebrates on reefs. A suspension feeder.

Tentacles held up into the water column to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Each tentacle is then inserted in turn into the mouth to be licked clean and recoated in sticky mucous before being held aloft again. The gut contents consist of a mix of organic particles including unicellular algae, pieces of algae, diatoms, sponge spicules, etc.

No details for this species, but in most sea cucumbers sexes are separate and sperm and eggs released via broadcast spawning and develop into planktonic larvae that are dispersed by ocean currents before settling onto suitable substrata.

Often confused with Pentacta doliolum with which if occurs in mixed aggregations. The two species are similar in size and shape, but P. doliolum is dark purple to black (especially dark in locations exposed to bright sunlight) and has a distinctly lighter flattened sole. (The main taxonomic feature separating the species is in fact the microscopic shapes of the ossicles in the body wall, which form round cup-like baskets and 4-holed buttons in this species).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 240).

Foster, GG & Hodgson, AN (1996). Feeding, tentacle and gut morphology in five species of southern African intertidal holothuroids (Echinodermata). African Zoology, 31(2), 70-79.

Thandar, AS (1991). The cucumariid holothurians of southern Africa with the erection of a new genus. African Zoology, 26(3), 115-139.

Thandar, AS (2022). A Taxonomic Monograph of the Sea Cucumbers of Southern Africa (Echinodermata: Holothuriodea). Suricata 9. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria. (p. 115).
